We will typically be concerned with the inclusions $k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)$ and $k\hookrightarrow \Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.

\begin{remark}  We may view the categories $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ etc as categories of monoidal functors \cite{KW}, in which case these adjunctions suggest a formal analogy with Verdier duality which could be further explored.
\end{remark}

The functors $T$ and $\Gamma$ preserve weak equivalences between fibrant objects (and hence all objects).  The functors $L$ and $\Phi$ preserve weak equivalences between cofibrant objects, and so cofibrant replacement will yield a well defined functor on the homotopy category.  Let $\tilde{\Phi}({\mathcal}{Q}):=\Phi(q{\mathcal}{Q})$ and similarly for $L$, where $q$ means a choice of cofibrant replacement {\it in the undercategory}.  Then we have adjunctions $(\tilde{L}_f, \Gamma_f)$ and $(\tilde{\Phi}_\iota, T_\iota)$ between the respective homotopy categories corresponding to any morphism $f$ and any inclusion $\iota$.  We may now record the following lemma for future use.

\begin{lemma}\label{welem2}  Let $A\stackrel{\iota}\hookrightarrow A\oplus B \stackrel{f}\longrightarrow A\oplus C$ be a sequence of morphisms of associative dg algebras where $f$ is of the form $f=id_A\oplus\bar{f}$, and where $\iota$ is inclusion.  If $f$ is a weak equivalence then for every ${\mathcal}{Q}\in (A\oplus C)$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences of $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ connecting
prevtext:
\title{Hyper-commutative algebras and cyclic cohomology}
\author{Benjamin C. Ward}

  






\begin{abstract} This paper investigates a chain model for the Deligne-Mumford operad formed by homotopically trivializing the circle in a chain model for the framed little disks.  The latter acts on the deformation complex of a multiplicative cyclic operad and under degeneration of cyclic cohomology the homotopy BV (resp. homotopy gravity) algebra on Hochschild (resp. cyclic) cochains lifts to an algebra over the former.  In particular we interpret the gravity brackets as obstructions to degeneration of cyclic cohomology.
\end{abstract}
\maketitle
\section*{Introduction}

A differential graded Batalin-Vilkovisky (BV) algebra enhanced with a trivialization of the $\Delta$ operator is equivalent to a hyper-commutative (HyCom) algebra \cite{DCV,KMS,DC}.  This relationship may be described in the language of operads, where BV and HyCom algebras are represented respectively by the homology operads of genus 0 moduli spaces of surfaces with boundary \cite{G94} and by the Deligne-Mumford compactification of the moduli space of surfaces with punctures \cite{GetMod}.  In practice BV algebras often arise as the homology or cohomology of a geometric, topological or algebraic object, and the chain level structure can only be expected to be BV up-to-homotopy.  This is the case for example when studying Hochschild cochain operations via the cyclic Deligne conjecture \cite{KCyclic}.  More generally, this is the case when considering the deformation complex of a cyclic operad ${\mathcal}{O}$ with $A_\infty$ multiplication $\mu$.  We denote such a deformation complex $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$.

On the other hand, the results of \cite{Ward2} show that the complex of cyclic invariants associated to such data carries a compatible structure of an algebra over chains on the {\it open} moduli space of punctured Riemann spheres.  This complex of invariants is a generalization of Connes' $C^\ast_\lambda$-complex and will be denoted $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$.  Its cohomology $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ generalizes the notion of the cyclic cohomology of a cyclic $k$-module.  It is natural to ask for conditions under which this action of the open moduli space lifts to an action of an operad of chains on the Deligne-Mumford compactification.

In a BV algebra the $\Delta$ operator corresponds to an action of the circle at a boundary component.  In the homotopy theory of $S^1$-spaces, trivialization of the circle action corresponds to degeneration of the cyclic (co)homology of an associated cyclic object.  Thus it is reasonable to expect that degeneration of the cyclic cohomology will permit such a lifting.  We prove the following result:

\begin{nonumbertheorem}  Let $\mu\colon {\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ be a map of cyclic operads.  Let $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ and $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ be the associated deformation and cyclic deformation complexes of $\mu$.  If the cyclic cohomology degenerates then the homotopy BV (resp. homotopy gravity) algebra structures lift to compatible homotopy hyper-commutative algebras.  In particular, inclusion $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\to CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ extends to an $\infty$-morphism of ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$-algebras.
\end{nonumbertheorem}

Examples of the complexes $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ and $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ to which this result applies include Hochschild and cyclic cochain complexes of Frobenius or cyclic $A_\infty$ algebras/categories, singular and equivariant cochains of $S^1$-spaces, as well as complexes computing string topology; homology and $S^1$-equivariant homology of the loop space of a closed oriented manifold, see \cite{Ward2} for these and other examples.

Formulating precise conditions under which the Hochschild to cyclic spectral sequence degenerates is a question of active study \cite{KS2}.  This question is of particular interest when studying homological mirror symmetry and categorical models of quantum cohomology \cite{BK,Manin}, which provide us with an expectation that the known BV/gravity structure should lift under degeneration.  Our result further says that, under degeneration and if the chain level structure can be seen as cyclic, the lifting can be performed at the chain level.  Pursing this chain level structure in such geometric examples with an eye toward a chain level lift of Gromov-Witten invariants should be an interesting avenue for future study.

In proving this result we start with a chain model for the framed little disks given in \cite{Ward1} which we denote ${\mathsf{fM}}$.  Alternatively we could use cellular chains on Cacti \cite{Vor}, \cite{KCacti}.  These chain models have $\Delta^2=0$ and thus are susceptible to the language of mixed complexes.  Combining the constructions of \cite{KMS} and formality of the Deligne-Mumford (cyclic) operad \cite{GNPR} it is straight forward to prove:

\begin{nonumbertheorem}  Homotopically trivializing the $\Delta$-operator in ${\mathsf{fM}}$ gives a chain model for the hyper-commutative operad.
\end{nonumbertheorem}

This chain model is denoted ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$ and it is, to an extent, combinatorially tractable.  For example the fundamental class of $\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_4$ is represented by a union of 14 2-cells.  The combinatorics of ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$ are based on planar trees with three types of vertices, see Section $\ref{combsec}$.  The following table summarizes the chain models for moduli spaces which act on such deformation complexes.  (Note that the assumption that ${\mathcal}{O}$ is cyclic is not needed in the first row).


\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c}
{\bf Moduli }				      &			{\bf Algebras'} 	& {\bf Chain }					   &  {\bf Acts on /}                    &   {\bf Combin-} \\
{\bf Space}               &     {\bf  name  }    &     {\bf  Model }       &  {\bf theorem}                      &    {\bf atorics}    \\ \hline
points in           &   \multirow{2}{*}{Gersten-}        &   \multirow{2}{*}{$\mathsf{M}$  of \cite{KS}}             &  $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$.      & black and white   \\
 the plane:         &   \multirow{2}{*}{haber}    &    \multirow{2}{*}{(minimal operad)}      & $A_\infty$ Deligne-            &(or b/w)  planar            \\
 ${\mathcal}{D}_2$         &          &                             &  conjecture               & rooted trees \\ 
\hline 
surfaces with                  & \multirow{3}{*}{BV} &  \multirow{2}{*}{$\mathsf{fM}$}  &  $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$.   &  b/w planar       \\

$f{\mathcal}{D}_2\sim\widehat{{\mathcal}{M}}_\ast$  &                     &          & Deligne conj.              &  with spines   \\ 
\hline 
surfaces with        & \multirow{3}{*}{gravity}      & \multirow{2}{*}{$\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright$}  &  $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$)   &   b/w planar \\

\hline 
Deligne-Mumford           & HyCom            &    \multirow{2}{*}{${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$}     &      $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$.              & b/w/gray    \\

\bigskip

 
In this paper we assume familiarity with operads and cyclic operads, references for which include \cite{GeK1,MSS,LV}.  We also assume familiarity with moduli space operads in genus $0$ and their homology, references for which include \cite{G94,GetMod,KSV}.
\subsection*{Acknowledgment}  This paper was written at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, whose support I gratefully acknowledge.  Thanks are due to Gabriel C. Drummond-Cole, Yuan Gao, Ralph Kaufmann, Dennis Sullivan, and Bruno Vallette for helpful discussions along the way.  
\tableofcontents

\section{The model categorical framework}  

Let ${\mathcal}{O}ps$ be the category of reduced operads valued in the category of differential graded (dg) vector spaces over a field $k$ of characteristic $0$.  Reduced means we restrict attention to arities $n\geq 1$.  The category ${\mathcal}{O}ps$ is a model category such that forgetting to symmetric sequences creates weak equivalences and fibrations \cite{BMo}.  The reduced assumption will be needed to ensure that this model category is left proper; a pushout of a weak equivalence along a cofibration is a weak equivalence (see \cite{BB} Theorem 0.1). 

We consider an associative algebra to be an operad concentrated in arity $1$.  Here we may consider either unital associative algebras or operads without units.  For an associative algebra $A$ we define $A$-${\mathcal}{O}$ps to be the undercategory $A\searrow {\mathcal}{O}ps$.  Note we often abuse notation by writing eg ${\mathcal}{Q}\in A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ and not $A\stackrel{\alpha}\to{\mathcal}{Q} \in A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$.  Note that the undercategory of a left proper model category is a left proper model category where forgetting to the original category creates all three classes of distinguished morphisms. 


Let $f\colon A\to B$ be a morphism between dg associative algebras $A$ and $B$.  We define $\Gamma_f\colon B$-${\mathcal}{O}ps\to A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ to be the functor induced by concatenation with $f$.  The subscript notation will be suppressed when appropriate.  Note that $\Gamma$ preserves weak equivalences and fibrations and since $\Gamma$ is a right adjoint, it is a right Quillen functor.  The left adjoint $L$ can be realized as a left Kan extension or as a pushout of operads ${\mathcal}{O}\leftarrow A \rightarrow B$.

\begin{lemma}\label{welem}  If $f$ is a quasi-isomorphism, the Quillen adjunction $(L,\Gamma)$ is a Quillen equivalence.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}  If $A\to{\mathcal}{O}$ is a cofibrant object in $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ then the map $A\to{\mathcal}{O}$ is a cofibration in ${\mathcal}{O}ps$.  Using left properness of this category we know the pushout of $f$ along this cofibration is a weak equivalence ${\mathcal}{O}\stackrel{\sim}\to L{\mathcal}{O}$ in ${\mathcal}{O}ps$.  In particular ${\mathcal}{O}\to \Gamma L{\mathcal}{O}$ is a weak equivalence in $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$.  This along with the fact that $\Gamma$ reflects weak equivalences proves the claim via the standard theory (see \cite{Hovey} Cor. 1.3.16).
\end{proof}


We now consider the special case of an inclusion $\iota\colon A\hookrightarrow A\oplus B$ between dg associative algebras $A$ and $A\oplus B$.  We define $T_\iota\colon A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps\to (A\oplus B)$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ to be the trivial extension by $0$.  It is again immediately clear from the model structure on the undercategories that $T$ preserves weak equivalences and fibrations and since $T$ is a right adjoint, it is a right Quillen functor.  We define its left adjoint $\Phi$ on a morphism $\epsilon\colon A\oplus B \to {\mathcal}{P}$ by taking the quotient ${\mathcal}{P}/(\epsilon(B))$.

In particular for such an inclusion we have a pair of adjunctions:

We will typically be concerned with the inclusions $k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)$ and $k\hookrightarrow \Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.

\begin{remark}  We may view the categories $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ etc as categories of monoidal functors \cite{KW}, in which case these adjunctions suggest a formal analogy with Verdier duality which could be further explored.
\end{remark}

The functors $T$ and $\Gamma$ preserve weak equivalences between fibrant objects (and hence all objects).  The functors $L$ and $\Phi$ preserve weak equivalences between cofibrant objects, and so cofibrant replacement will yield a well defined functor on the homotopy category.  Let $\tilde{\Phi}({\mathcal}{Q}):=\Phi(q{\mathcal}{Q})$ and similarly for $L$, where $q$ means a choice of cofibrant replacement {\it in the undercategory}.  Then we have adjunctions $(\tilde{L}_f, \Gamma_f)$ and $(\tilde{\Phi}_\iota, T_\iota)$ between the respective homotopy categories corresponding to any morphism $f$ and any inclusion $\iota$.  We may now record the following lemma for future use.

\begin{lemma}\label{welem2}  Let $A\stackrel{\iota}\hookrightarrow A\oplus B \stackrel{f}\longrightarrow A\oplus C$ be a sequence of morphisms of associative dg algebras where $f$ is of the form $f=id_A\oplus\bar{f}$, and where $\iota$ is inclusion.  If $f$ is a weak equivalence then for every ${\mathcal}{Q}\in (A\oplus C)$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences of $A$-${\mathcal}{O}ps$ connecting

nexttext:
when we speak of lifting a ${\mathcal}{Q}$-algebra to a $\Phi_{KMS}({\mathcal}{Q})$ algebra we use the corollary (i.e. inclusion), which is not the same as composition in the diagram.

\section{Cyclic cohomology operations.}\label{cycsec}  In this section we give an overview of the mixed complex associated to a multiplicative cyclic operad, its associated spectral sequence, and the accompanying homotopy BV and gravity structures. 

In this section we let ${\mathcal}{O}$ be a unital cyclic operad valued in dg vector spaces graded cohomologically.  We define ${\mathcal}{O}^\ast:=\prod_n\Sigma\mathfrak{s}{\mathcal}{O}(n)$, where $\Sigma$ is the degree shift operator and $\mathfrak{s}$ is the operadic suspension.  This vector space has a natural Lie bracket $\{-,-\}$ for which a Maurer-Cartan element is equivalent to a morphism $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$.  Given this data we form a differential in the usual way:  $d_\mu:= d_{\mathcal}{O}+\{\mu,-\}$, where $d_{\mathcal}{O}$ is the original (arity-wise) differential in ${\mathcal}{O}$.

\begin{definition}  Let $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to {\mathcal}{O}$ be a map of cyclic operads.  Define $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ to be the complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast, d_\mu)$.  This complex is called the deformation complex of $\mu$.
\end{definition}

The complex $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ can be endowed with a square zero operator $\Delta$ of degree $-1$ analogous to the construction of Connes' B operator.  Explicitly $\Delta:=Ns_0(1-t)$ where $s_0$ is the extra degeneracy (via the unit), $t$ is the arity-wise cyclic operator and $N$ is the arity-wise sum $\Sigma_i t^i$  (see eg \cite{Loday} Chapter 2).  This operator is square zero and commutes with $d_\mu$ and so $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$ is a mixed complex.

To this mixed complex we will associate a bicomplex with vertical differential $d_\mu$ (pointing up) and horizontal differential $\Delta$ (pointing right) and filter this bicomplex by columns.  We would like this filtration to be exhaustive, so for simplicity we impose the following 
{\bf assumption:} the complex ${\mathcal}{O}^\ast$ is supported in non-negative degrees.  This will be the case if ${\mathcal}{O}(n)$ is contained in degrees $\geq -n$.  Of course there are weaker boundedness conditions under which this filtration is exhaustive.  In this case we may form the bicomplex in the first quadrant.  We filter this bicomplex by columns and construct the associated spectral sequence.  The $0$-page has $E_0^{pq}=\Sigma^{2p}{\mathcal}{O}^{q-p}=\prod_{q=0}^\infty\Sigma^{q+2p}{\mathcal}{O}(n)_{q-p-n}$ the $1$-page has $E_1^{pq}=\Sigma^{2p}H^{q-p}({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d)=\Sigma^{2p}HH^{q-p}({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$, and the $2$-page has $E_2^{pq}=H^p(\Sigma^{2\ast}HH^{q-\ast}({\mathcal}{O},\mu), [\Delta])$.  In particular the $1$-page differential is $d^1:=[\Delta]$.  

If $[\Delta]=0$ on HH then there exists a chain operation of degree $-2$ whose boundary is $\Delta$, from which we can build the 2-page differential.  Explicitly, in the notation of the previous section $d^2=\Delta\beta_1$.  Likewise $d^2$ will be zero if there exists a chain operation of degree $-4$, whose boundary is $\Delta\beta_1$, and explicitly one may calculate $d^3=\Delta(\beta_2-\beta_1^2)$.  Continuing in this vein we see existence of the $\beta_i$ is necessary and sufficient for degeneration:

\begin{lemma}(\cite{DSV} Proposition 1.5) Degeneration in this spectral sequence at the $1$-page is equivalent to a trivialization of $\Delta$ in the sense of Definition $\ref{degdef}$.
\end{lemma}

This spectral sequence converges to the product total complex ToT of the original bicomplex.  The homology of the total complex is the cyclic cohomology of the pair $({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ and will be denoted $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$.  It can be computed in two ways: via the total complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d+z\Delta)$, where $deg(z)=2$, or by the product complex of invariants.  Define $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu):=(\prod_n {\mathcal}{O}(n)^{\mathbb{Z}_{n+1}}, d_\mu)$.  The complex $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ may also be called the cyclic deformation complex of $\mu$, and it computes $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ by the following Lemma.

\begin{lemma}\label{cyclem2} Inclusion $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)\hookrightarrow ({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d+z\Delta)$ is a quasi-isomorphism.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}  This follows from Proposition 2.16 of \cite{Ward2} and a standard `killing contractible complexes' argument as in \cite{Loday} 2.4.3.
\end{proof}

In the case that the spectral sequence associated to the mixed complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$ degenerates at the $1$-page, we have $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\cong HH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)[[z]]$.  This happens precisely when there is a trivialization of $\Delta$ so we make the following definition:

\begin{definition}\label{degdef2}  We say the cyclic cohomology of $({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ degenerates if there exists a trivialization of $\Delta$ in the mixed complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Operations on $CH$ and $C_\lambda$}

In the case that $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ is simply a map of operads (not cyclic) the classical Deligne conjecture says that $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ is an algebra over a chain model for the little disks operad.  In the $A_\infty$ case this chain operad was constructed by Kontsevich and Soibelman \cite{KS} and was denoted $\mathsf{M}$ for minimal operad.  It is an insertion operad of planar 2-colored trees.  

If we now remember the cyclic structure of $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ we may upgrade the complex $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ to an algebra over a chain model for the framed little disks.  In the cyclic $A_\infty$ setting this operad was constructed in \cite{Ward1}, where it was denoted ${\mathcal}{TS}_\infty$.  In hindsight, this $\infty$ notation might be confusing, so we will instead use the notation ${\mathsf{fM}}$ for `framed minimal operad'.  For details see \cite{Ward1}, but the important properties of the chain operad ${\mathsf{fM}}$ are:
\begin{enumerate}
\item  There exists a zig-zag of quasi isomorphisms of operads between ${\mathsf{fM}}$ and singular chains on the framed little disks.
\item  In particular there exists a zig-zag ${\mathsf{fM}}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow{\mathcal}{BV}_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{BV}$.
\item  The dg operad ${\mathsf{fM}}$ acts on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ for any such $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ recovering the known BV structure on cohomology.
\item  ${\mathsf{fM}}$ is constructed as an insertion operad of planar 2-colored trees along with marked points on the boundaries of vertices, which are called spines.
\end{enumerate} 

We could instead consider the chain model provided by cellular chains on normalized cacti \cite{Vor, KCacti} which has all of the properties above, except requires the multiplication is associative.

Since the invariants $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ form a $d_\mu$-closed subspace of $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ we can ask which of the operations in ${\mathsf{fM}}$ restrict to this complex.  In other words which operations preserve the property of $t$-invariance?  This question was answered in \cite{Ward2} and the answer forms a sub-operad $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright\subset {\mathsf{fM}}$ whose homology is the homology operad of the punctured Riemann spheres, called the gravity operad in \cite{Geteq}.  In particular this endows the cyclic cohomology $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ with the structure of a gravity algebra and the natural map $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\to HH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ is a map of gravity algebras.  It is natural to ask when this structure lifts to the compactification, and this question is answered in the next section.



\section{Collecting Results.}
Collecting the main results in this section.  We continue to write $\Phi$ (with suppressed subscript) in place of $\Phi_{k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)}$.  We define ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}:=\Phi_{KMS}({\mathsf{fM}})$.


\begin{theorem}\label{chainmodelthm} ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$ is a chain model for the hyper-commutative operad.  Explicitly, there exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences of dg operads ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow \dots \stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow S_\ast(\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1})$.   
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}  Here $S_\ast$ denotes singular chains with coefficients in the field $k$.  Using formality of  the Deligne-Mumford operad $\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1}$, (see \cite{GNPR} Corollary 7.2.1) we know there exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences connecting ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om\sim S_\ast(\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1})$. From \cite{KMS} we know there is a weak equivalence ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om\stackrel{\sim}\to\Phi_{KMS}(BV)$.  So it remains to show that there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences $\tilde{\Phi}(BV) \sim \tilde{\Phi}({\mathsf{fM}})$.

The algebra $H^\ast(S^1)$ has a Koszul resolution given by taking the cobar construction $\Omega$ of the coalgebra $H_\ast(BS^1)$.  Let $\iota\colon k\hookrightarrow \Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$ be inclusion and let $f\colon\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)\to H^\ast(S^1)$ be the standard weak equivalence.  Then, since $f\circ \iota$ is the standard injection $k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)$ we endevor to show $\tilde{\Phi}_{f\circ \iota}({\mathcal}{BV}) \sim \tilde{\Phi}_{f\circ \iota}({\mathsf{fM}})$.  Note that ${\mathsf{fM}}$ is equivalent to ${\mathcal}{BV}$ in the category under $\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.  In particular there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences ${\mathsf{fM}}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow {\mathcal}{BV}_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{BV}$ under $\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.  Therefore $\tilde{\Phi}_\iota(\Gamma_f {\mathsf{fM}})\sim \tilde{\Phi}_\iota(\Gamma_f {\mathcal}{BV})$.  Applying Lemma $\ref{welem2}$ proves the claim.  
\end{proof}
We let ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$ denote the cobar resolution via the Koszul dual operad ${\mathcal}{G}rav$, i.e. ${\mathcal}{H}y{C}om_\infty:= \Omega {\mathcal}{G}rav^\ast$.  Cofibrancy of this operad gives us:
\begin{corollary}\label{HCinfcor} There exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences: ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow {\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om$.
\end{corollary}


We now give conditions such that the ${\mathsf{fM}}$ (resp. $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright$) algebra structures on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ (resp. $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu))$ lift to ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebras, understood via the sequence $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright\to{\mathsf{fM}} \to {\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$.

\begin{theorem}\label{algthm}  Let ${\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ be a map of cyclic operads and suppose the cyclic cohomology of $({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ degenerates (Definition $\ref{degdef2}$).  Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item  The ${\mathsf{fM}}$ algebra structure on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ lifts to an ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebra, and hence a ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$-algebra.
\item  The cyclic cohomology $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ has the structure of a hyper-commutative algebra lifting the gravity structure.  This structure arises from a ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$ structure on $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$.
\item  Inclusion $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\to CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ extends to an $\infty$-morphism between these ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$-algebra structures.
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof} The first statement follows from Corollary $\ref{KMScor}$ and Corollary $\ref{HCinfcor}$.  

For the second and third statement, we first use the obvious inclusion and projection maps $in\colon({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu)\leftrightarrows ({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d_\mu)\colon \pi$ with $\pi\circ in=id$ to furnish a morphism of operads $End_{({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu)}\to End_{({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d_\mu)}$.  Observe that with respect to the consequent structure, $\pi$ is a morphism of ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebras and hence of ${\mathcal}{H}y{C}om_\infty$-algebras.  

Under degeneration we have the commutative diagram:

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\mathcal{}}{Q}\stackrel{\sim}{\leftarrow}W({\mathcal{}}{Q})\rightarrow\Phi_{%
KMS}({\mathcal{}}{Q})" display="block"><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mover><mo movablelimits="false">←</mo><mo mathsize="142%" stretchy="false">∼</mo></mover><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mi>K</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>M</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

when we speak of lifting a ${\mathcal}{Q}$-algebra to a $\Phi_{KMS}({\mathcal}{Q})$ algebra we use the corollary (i.e. inclusion), which is not the same as composition in the diagram.

\section{Cyclic cohomology operations.}\label{cycsec}  In this section we give an overview of the mixed complex associated to a multiplicative cyclic operad, its associated spectral sequence, and the accompanying homotopy BV and gravity structures. 

In this section we let ${\mathcal}{O}$ be a unital cyclic operad valued in dg vector spaces graded cohomologically.  We define ${\mathcal}{O}^\ast:=\prod_n\Sigma\mathfrak{s}{\mathcal}{O}(n)$, where $\Sigma$ is the degree shift operator and $\mathfrak{s}$ is the operadic suspension.  This vector space has a natural Lie bracket $\{-,-\}$ for which a Maurer-Cartan element is equivalent to a morphism $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$.  Given this data we form a differential in the usual way:  $d_\mu:= d_{\mathcal}{O}+\{\mu,-\}$, where $d_{\mathcal}{O}$ is the original (arity-wise) differential in ${\mathcal}{O}$.

\begin{definition}  Let $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to {\mathcal}{O}$ be a map of cyclic operads.  Define $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ to be the complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast, d_\mu)$.  This complex is called the deformation complex of $\mu$.
\end{definition}

The complex $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ can be endowed with a square zero operator $\Delta$ of degree $-1$ analogous to the construction of Connes' B operator.  Explicitly $\Delta:=Ns_0(1-t)$ where $s_0$ is the extra degeneracy (via the unit), $t$ is the arity-wise cyclic operator and $N$ is the arity-wise sum $\Sigma_i t^i$  (see eg \cite{Loday} Chapter 2).  This operator is square zero and commutes with $d_\mu$ and so $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$ is a mixed complex.

To this mixed complex we will associate a bicomplex with vertical differential $d_\mu$ (pointing up) and horizontal differential $\Delta$ (pointing right) and filter this bicomplex by columns.  We would like this filtration to be exhaustive, so for simplicity we impose the following 
{\bf assumption:} the complex ${\mathcal}{O}^\ast$ is supported in non-negative degrees.  This will be the case if ${\mathcal}{O}(n)$ is contained in degrees $\geq -n$.  Of course there are weaker boundedness conditions under which this filtration is exhaustive.  In this case we may form the bicomplex in the first quadrant.  We filter this bicomplex by columns and construct the associated spectral sequence.  The $0$-page has $E_0^{pq}=\Sigma^{2p}{\mathcal}{O}^{q-p}=\prod_{q=0}^\infty\Sigma^{q+2p}{\mathcal}{O}(n)_{q-p-n}$ the $1$-page has $E_1^{pq}=\Sigma^{2p}H^{q-p}({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d)=\Sigma^{2p}HH^{q-p}({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$, and the $2$-page has $E_2^{pq}=H^p(\Sigma^{2\ast}HH^{q-\ast}({\mathcal}{O},\mu), [\Delta])$.  In particular the $1$-page differential is $d^1:=[\Delta]$.  

If $[\Delta]=0$ on HH then there exists a chain operation of degree $-2$ whose boundary is $\Delta$, from which we can build the 2-page differential.  Explicitly, in the notation of the previous section $d^2=\Delta\beta_1$.  Likewise $d^2$ will be zero if there exists a chain operation of degree $-4$, whose boundary is $\Delta\beta_1$, and explicitly one may calculate $d^3=\Delta(\beta_2-\beta_1^2)$.  Continuing in this vein we see existence of the $\beta_i$ is necessary and sufficient for degeneration:

\begin{lemma}(\cite{DSV} Proposition 1.5) Degeneration in this spectral sequence at the $1$-page is equivalent to a trivialization of $\Delta$ in the sense of Definition $\ref{degdef}$.
\end{lemma}

This spectral sequence converges to the product total complex ToT of the original bicomplex.  The homology of the total complex is the cyclic cohomology of the pair $({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ and will be denoted $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$.  It can be computed in two ways: via the total complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d+z\Delta)$, where $deg(z)=2$, or by the product complex of invariants.  Define $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu):=(\prod_n {\mathcal}{O}(n)^{\mathbb{Z}_{n+1}}, d_\mu)$.  The complex $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ may also be called the cyclic deformation complex of $\mu$, and it computes $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ by the following Lemma.

\begin{lemma}\label{cyclem2} Inclusion $C^\ast_\lambda({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)\hookrightarrow ({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d+z\Delta)$ is a quasi-isomorphism.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}  This follows from Proposition 2.16 of \cite{Ward2} and a standard `killing contractible complexes' argument as in \cite{Loday} 2.4.3.
\end{proof}

In the case that the spectral sequence associated to the mixed complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$ degenerates at the $1$-page, we have $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\cong HH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)[[z]]$.  This happens precisely when there is a trivialization of $\Delta$ so we make the following definition:

\begin{definition}\label{degdef2}  We say the cyclic cohomology of $({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ degenerates if there exists a trivialization of $\Delta$ in the mixed complex $({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu,\Delta)$.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Operations on $CH$ and $C_\lambda$}

In the case that $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ is simply a map of operads (not cyclic) the classical Deligne conjecture says that $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ is an algebra over a chain model for the little disks operad.  In the $A_\infty$ case this chain operad was constructed by Kontsevich and Soibelman \cite{KS} and was denoted $\mathsf{M}$ for minimal operad.  It is an insertion operad of planar 2-colored trees.  

If we now remember the cyclic structure of $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ we may upgrade the complex $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ to an algebra over a chain model for the framed little disks.  In the cyclic $A_\infty$ setting this operad was constructed in \cite{Ward1}, where it was denoted ${\mathcal}{TS}_\infty$.  In hindsight, this $\infty$ notation might be confusing, so we will instead use the notation ${\mathsf{fM}}$ for `framed minimal operad'.  For details see \cite{Ward1}, but the important properties of the chain operad ${\mathsf{fM}}$ are:
\begin{enumerate}
\item  There exists a zig-zag of quasi isomorphisms of operads between ${\mathsf{fM}}$ and singular chains on the framed little disks.
\item  In particular there exists a zig-zag ${\mathsf{fM}}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow{\mathcal}{BV}_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{BV}$.
\item  The dg operad ${\mathsf{fM}}$ acts on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ for any such $\mu\colon{\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ recovering the known BV structure on cohomology.
\item  ${\mathsf{fM}}$ is constructed as an insertion operad of planar 2-colored trees along with marked points on the boundaries of vertices, which are called spines.
\end{enumerate} 

We could instead consider the chain model provided by cellular chains on normalized cacti \cite{Vor, KCacti} which has all of the properties above, except requires the multiplication is associative.

Since the invariants $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ form a $d_\mu$-closed subspace of $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ we can ask which of the operations in ${\mathsf{fM}}$ restrict to this complex.  In other words which operations preserve the property of $t$-invariance?  This question was answered in \cite{Ward2} and the answer forms a sub-operad $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright\subset {\mathsf{fM}}$ whose homology is the homology operad of the punctured Riemann spheres, called the gravity operad in \cite{Geteq}.  In particular this endows the cyclic cohomology $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ with the structure of a gravity algebra and the natural map $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\to HH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ is a map of gravity algebras.  It is natural to ask when this structure lifts to the compactification, and this question is answered in the next section.



\section{Collecting Results.}
Collecting the main results in this section.  We continue to write $\Phi$ (with suppressed subscript) in place of $\Phi_{k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)}$.  We define ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}:=\Phi_{KMS}({\mathsf{fM}})$.


\begin{theorem}\label{chainmodelthm} ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$ is a chain model for the hyper-commutative operad.  Explicitly, there exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences of dg operads ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow \dots \stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow S_\ast(\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1})$.   
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}  Here $S_\ast$ denotes singular chains with coefficients in the field $k$.  Using formality of  the Deligne-Mumford operad $\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1}$, (see \cite{GNPR} Corollary 7.2.1) we know there exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences connecting ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om\sim S_\ast(\overline{{\mathcal}{M}}_{\ast+1})$. From \cite{KMS} we know there is a weak equivalence ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om\stackrel{\sim}\to\Phi_{KMS}(BV)$.  So it remains to show that there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences $\tilde{\Phi}(BV) \sim \tilde{\Phi}({\mathsf{fM}})$.

The algebra $H^\ast(S^1)$ has a Koszul resolution given by taking the cobar construction $\Omega$ of the coalgebra $H_\ast(BS^1)$.  Let $\iota\colon k\hookrightarrow \Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$ be inclusion and let $f\colon\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)\to H^\ast(S^1)$ be the standard weak equivalence.  Then, since $f\circ \iota$ is the standard injection $k\hookrightarrow H^\ast(S^1)$ we endevor to show $\tilde{\Phi}_{f\circ \iota}({\mathcal}{BV}) \sim \tilde{\Phi}_{f\circ \iota}({\mathsf{fM}})$.  Note that ${\mathsf{fM}}$ is equivalent to ${\mathcal}{BV}$ in the category under $\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.  In particular there is a zig-zag of weak equivalences ${\mathsf{fM}}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow {\mathcal}{BV}_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{BV}$ under $\Omega H_\ast(BS^1)$.  Therefore $\tilde{\Phi}_\iota(\Gamma_f {\mathsf{fM}})\sim \tilde{\Phi}_\iota(\Gamma_f {\mathcal}{BV})$.  Applying Lemma $\ref{welem2}$ proves the claim.  
\end{proof}
We let ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$ denote the cobar resolution via the Koszul dual operad ${\mathcal}{G}rav$, i.e. ${\mathcal}{H}y{C}om_\infty:= \Omega {\mathcal}{G}rav^\ast$.  Cofibrancy of this operad gives us:
\begin{corollary}\label{HCinfcor} There exists a zig-zag of weak equivalences: ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}\stackrel{\sim}\leftarrow {\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty\stackrel{\sim}\rightarrow {\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om$.
\end{corollary}


We now give conditions such that the ${\mathsf{fM}}$ (resp. $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright$) algebra structures on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ (resp. $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu))$ lift to ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebras, understood via the sequence $\mathsf{M}_\circlearrowright\to{\mathsf{fM}} \to {\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$.

\begin{theorem}\label{algthm}  Let ${\mathcal}{A}_\infty\to{\mathcal}{O}$ be a map of cyclic operads and suppose the cyclic cohomology of $({\mathcal}{O}, \mu)$ degenerates (Definition $\ref{degdef2}$).  Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item  The ${\mathsf{fM}}$ algebra structure on $CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ lifts to an ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebra, and hence a ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$-algebra.
\item  The cyclic cohomology $HC^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ has the structure of a hyper-commutative algebra lifting the gravity structure.  This structure arises from a ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$ structure on $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$.
\item  Inclusion $C_\lambda^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)\to CH^\ast({\mathcal}{O},\mu)$ extends to an $\infty$-morphism between these ${\mathcal}{H}y{\mathcal}{C}om_\infty$-algebra structures.
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof} The first statement follows from Corollary $\ref{KMScor}$ and Corollary $\ref{HCinfcor}$.  

For the second and third statement, we first use the obvious inclusion and projection maps $in\colon({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu)\leftrightarrows ({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d_\mu)\colon \pi$ with $\pi\circ in=id$ to furnish a morphism of operads $End_{({\mathcal}{O}^\ast,d_\mu)}\to End_{({\mathcal}{O}^\ast[[z]], d_\mu)}$.  Observe that with respect to the consequent structure, $\pi$ is a morphism of ${\mathsf{fM}}_{hS^1}$-algebras and hence of ${\mathcal}{H}y{C}om_\infty$-algebras.  

Under degeneration we have the commutative diagram:
